In India, Theravada form of Buddhism was one of about 16 schools of Buddhism that preserved the early practice as the Buddha himself had taught it in its sort of early simple form. As time went on, after the Buddha's death, the Buddha lived about 2,500 years ago, other practices developed that were evolutions from his teaching. Something called Mahayana and then out of that something called Vajrayana. Mahayana means the great vehicle. Vajrayana means the diamond vehicle. So I know that this may seem like a lot of technical information, but I think many of you will read books about the history and you'd like to know where the practice comes from. So put simply, vipassana is the representative practice of the Theravada School of Buddhism. The Theravada School of Buddhism is sometimes called Southern Buddhism because it's in Southeast Asia. It's sometimes called Pali Buddhism because it uses this language Pali, which is very similar to the language the Buddha himself spoke. He didn't speak Sanskrit. So the early Buddhists are sometimes referred to as Hinayana. The discovery that the Buddha made, that made him the Buddha, the awakened one, was an extraordinary discovery. I rank it as one of the major discoveries of our human species. There's the discovery of fire, there's the discovery of the Pythagorean theorem, there's a few very, very basic important things that cultures discover, the human species has discovered. And what the Buddha discovered ranks as one of these very fundamental, very important things. What he discovered was that if we bring the quality of exceedingly precise observation to the ordinary flow of experience, the operation of these six senses, hearing, seeing, smelling, tasting, the feeling body, and the thinking mind, if we bring an extraordinary degree of precise attention to the ordinary flow of the senses, and at the same time we bring a quality of not interfering with the operation of the senses, simply allowing hearing to play itself out as hearing, seeing to arise as seeing, the feelings in the body to spread and move and dance their dance, live their life as they wish, and the thoughts to come and go in their own natural pattern. If we bring to this ordinary flow of experience an extraordinary degree of attentiveness and non-interference, then we initiate a process and that process has two aspects. One is an aspect of the development of deep insight. We start to get understandings, understandings that are not merely related to our individual life and our individual personality, but understandings that are deeper than the specifics of our life. We get understandings into the generic issues, what is the nature of suffering, and how can we experience pain without it turning into suffering, physical pain, psychological pain, of any cause, of any quality, of any intensity. How can we experience, we have to feel, we're feeling beings, we're not rocks. How can we experience pain without it getting in the way of the perfection of the moment? We get insight, we actually see how that can be directly. How can we experience pleasure in a way that we get really lasting satisfaction, that it does not become a compulsion and that our base level of fulfillment is permanently changed by having experienced the pleasure? Usually when we experience pleasure, it does not change our baseline of fulfillment, it does not transform how we live the rest of our life. And in fact, usually it turns into craving and need and drivenness. So how can we, we must experience pain in this life, how can we experience pain without it getting in the way of the perfection of the moment? We must experience pleasure in this life, how can we experience pleasure with really lasting satisfaction and without it becoming neediness? What is the nature of the experience of self? What is the nature of the experience of oneness? What is the substance of experience? Hearing, seeing, smelling, tasting, the feeling body and the thinking mind. Ultimately, out of what atoms are these experiences built? The self and the world. Subjectively speaking, as arising in consciousness, what are they made out of? If we observe very carefully under a microscope, the cells of the tissues of the human body, we can actually see what those tissues are made out of and there would be no way that we could know the cell theory of life without a microscope to observe the structure of life. With the naked eye, it's not at all evident. Through logic, it is not at all evident that our bodies are built of teeny, trillions of teeny little cells. So in the same way, it is not at all evident to the average person what the substance of experience is, even though that person will live their entire life in the world of hearing, seeing, smelling, tasting, the feeling body and the thinking mind. They will never know at a microscopic level the single substance out of which that experience is built. So one of the things that happens as we bring the quality of precise observation and non-interference to the flow of these senses is that we go through not just one, but a sequence of ever deepening insights into very, very fundamental and broad issues. And of course, when a fundamental issue is cracked, then we have a powerful tool to deal with the specific issues. All of those specific issues become immediately resolved when we resolve the general issues. So we're talking about heavy guns, we're talking about deep work, and we're talking about an unfolding of fundamental insight that will go on throughout your whole life, a sequence of ever deepening understandings. I mentioned that a process that involves two aspects is initiated by precise observation with non-interference. The second aspect, in addition to the sequence of insights, a person goes through a sequence of releases. Releases of the stored poison and pain of a lifetime, releases of the forces that limit perception and behavior. We all notice year after year, the same limiting forces on our behavior seem to act however much we may want to change. However much the surface mind says it wants to live a certain way, there's some force in the depth of the mind that prevents that from happening. Year after year, the same limiting forces are influencing behavior. And second by second, instant by instant, we are aware that our perceptions are less than beatific. For most people, it doesn't seem like sitting in this room right now, listening to this talk, being a little sleepy at night, that we're sitting in paradise. It seems like less than paradise here. But that's only because of these limiting forces that are acting upon us. If we were free from those limiting forces, as we become free from those limiting forces, more and more ordinary experiences, just sitting around, listening to people talk, riding in the car, seem to be like a blessing, like a prayer, beatific, spiritual. This is what in the Christian tradition was called the practice of the presence of God. It meant you didn't have to do special prayers. The ordinary operation of your senses became prayers because the true spiritual nature of the substance of experience was evident to you. So, the forces that keep us in the same negative behavior patterns year after year and prevent the operation of ordinary experience from being a spiritual transcendent experience, those forces percolate up to the surface as yucky states of the body and agitated states of the mind. And what happens is, as they boil up to the surface as we sit here, we just observe them. We don't do anything at all. We just are very precise and allow them to dance their dance. So we don't reinforce them. We don't react to them by either going unconscious or by buying into them or by pushing away. Usually when a negative force arises within a person, the person will either try to anesthetize themselves by turning away or maybe actually drugging themselves or distracting themselves or they will reject that negativity and long for it to go away and resist it or they will buy into it and identify with it and act on it. But in addition to buying into it or trying to push it away or trying to ignore it, there's another possibility. Watch it with detachment. If we try to push it away or if we try to turn away from it or if we try to, or if we identify with it, then we recharge that negativity. But if we just observe it and remain very, very conscious, its energy becomes dissipated each time it arises. Like a battery, it eventually loses its source of energy and dies. So in addition to the sequence of insights, really deep and fascinating spiritual insights that a person goes through, they go through a sequence of releases, of blockages, of negative forces, of stored, undigested life material. It's going to come up as you sit. In fact, I don't want to scare anybody away from this retreat, but it's entirely possible that most of the time as you sit there, your experience is going to be two things. However, what you're going to discover is that you're going to be relating to those phenomena differently than you would relate to them in daily life, because you're here to meditate and you're going to be given resources. There's a technique. So that your mind will be agitated and you'll just observe that. Your body will be yucky and you'll just observe that. Things that used to bother you won't bother you so much. Feelings of separation and alienation that were always there suddenly aren't there anymore. Your base level of feeling fulfilled with even simple things seems to have gone up. Just the simple things of having a piece of toast or driving down the road seems to have a heightened sense of brightness and wonder. It's because, although you weren't aware of it at the time, the blockages to happiness, the sources of unhappiness, were welling up as you were sitting here. And you were actually working them off, literally watching them to death. That's what vipassana is. It's watching the sources of unhappiness to death. If you go out there and actively try to slay them, they just get stronger and stronger. But if you allow them to play themselves out and watch, then they will simply die a natural death quite gracefully. So we're going to practice two things. One is that we're going to take ordinary experience and develop an extraordinary degree of precision in awareness. And that precision in awareness, that continuity of awareness, that clarity of awareness, that discernment in awareness is called mindfulness, or in the sense, in the Pali, sati, S-A-T-I. The second thing we're going to be cultivating is we're going to give permission for the senses to simply operate. And we're going to not interfere. So if we have a pain in the leg and it wants to spread, we're going to let it spread. If we're feeling sleepy and there's a sleepy sensation and it wants to move in a certain way through the body, we're going to let it move that way. It doesn't mean that if it's hot, we're going to observe heat. Now it also means, it doesn't mean that we'll fail to open the windows or turn on the thermostat. But we'll take a stance as far as the circumstances go. We're not going to be passive about circumstances, but we are going to have an attitude of non-interfering with the actual operation of the senses themselves. And that attitude of non-interfering with the flow of experience is technically called equanimity. From the Latin, equis animus, meaning a balanced consciousness. A sense of balance, not being knocked off balance because of the different states that come up. So we're going to be cultivating two things with respect to ordinary experience. We'll be cultivating mindfulness and equanimity. This is going to also result in two things. Insights will begin to come, understandings, aha experiences. And the impurities in consciousness, the blockages, the sources of unhappiness, will come to the surface and they'll be observed and they'll literally boil off. And when the sources of unhappiness have been evacuated, then our natural state of happiness will become evident. Just as if there's a window and it's covered with dirt, if you clean away the dirt, the sun that was always there can shine through. You don't create the sun. So in this practice, we can't create enlightenment. We don't attempt to create enlightenment. It's already there. We're not trying to seek God. We're trying to rather do a methodical practice which will clean away the thing that stands between us and God. So what vipassana means is, the reason we use the Pali word is vipassana means the practice of the observation. One of the things that comes up as we're sitting here that I'm sure many of you have been thinking is I got better things to do with my time than sit here and feel the discomforts of my knees aching, my back aching, being sleepy, the pressures on the body, etc. We have a very strong conditioning to associate physical discomfort with something that has no redeeming feature whatsoever. It's true, isn't it? Our basic human conditioning, the basic conditioning of the species, is if we have discomfort, something's wrong. And things will only be right when that discomfort has been eliminated. Now, of course, it's entirely true that we can do certain things, we can manipulate circumstances, so as to minimalize discomfort in our lives.
